data.data: Initial comments:This report is the result of an on-site occupancy survey conducted on February 6, 2024, at Temple University Hospital, Inc-Main Campus., which included renovations for a Clean Utility Equipment Storage Room (Room A2-F212 ) on the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit (CICU)-Pavilion Building, on the 2nd floor and renovations for a Meditation Room (Room A104) on the 1st floor in the Ontario Street Lobby.  Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an on-site occupancy survey conducted on February 6, 2024, at Temple University Hospital, Inc-Main Campus., which included renovations for a Clean Utility Equipment Storage Room (Room A2-F212 ) on the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit (CICU)-Pavilion Building, on the 2nd floor and renovations for a Meditation Room (Room A104) on the 1st floor in the Ontario Street Lobby.  Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 3, 2024, and completed on January 4, 2024, at Temple University Hospital Inc-Episcopal Campus-Behavioral Health Units. It was determined the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998.   Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 3, 2024, and completed on January 4, 2024, at Temple University Hospital Inc-Episcopal Campus-Behavioral Health Units. It was determined the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998.   Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 3, 2024, and completed on January 4, 2024,  at Temple University Hospital Inc,-Episcopal Campus-Behavioral Health Units.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with requirements of the Chapter 5100 Mental Health regulations. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 3, 2024, and completed on January 4, 2024,  at Temple University Hospital Inc,-Episcopal Campus-Behavioral Health Units.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with requirements of the Chapter 5100 Mental Health regulations. Plan of Correction: 5100.16 (a) REQUIREMENT Review and Periodic Re-examination:5100.16  REVIEW AND PERIODIC REEXAMINATION	(a) At least once every 30 days, every person in treatment under the Act shall have his treatment plan reviewed. This review shall be based upon Section 108 (A) of the Act (50 P.S..7108 (A)). A report of the review and findings shall be summarized in the patient's clinical record.Observations:Based on review of the Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act, medical records (MR) and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure documentation of a 30-day review of the patient's Treatment Plan with findings summarized in the medical record in accordance with the Department of Human Services requirement for four of four medical records reviewed (MR1, MR2, MR8 and MR9).Findings include:A review of the Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act revealed "5100.16. Review and Periodic Reexamination. (a)  At least once every 30 days, every person in treatment under the Act shall have his treatment plan reviewed.  This review shall be based upon Section 108 (A) of the Act (50 P.S. 7108(A). A report of the review and findings shall be summarized in the patient's clinical record."A review on January 3, 2024, of MR1, admitted January 12, 2023, and discharged June 6, 2023, for Schizophrenia, revealed there was no documentation that a review of the patient's treatment plan with findings summarized in the medical record was completed at least once every 30 days as required by the Department of Human Services.  A review on January 4, 2024, of MR2, admitted July 18, 2023, and discharged August 11, 2023, for Schizophrenia/Polysubstance abuse, revealed there was no documentation that a review of the patient's treatment plan with findings summarized in the medical record was completed at least once every 30 days as required by the Department of Human Services.  A review on January 4, 2024, of MR8, a current inpatient, admitted October 20, 2023, for Unspecified Psychosis, revealed there was no documentation that a review of the patient's treatment plan with findings summarized in the medical record was completed at least once every 30 days as required by the Department of Human Services.  A review on January 4, 2024, of M9, a current inpatient, admitted October 17, 2023, for Schizophrenia, revealed there was no documentation that a review of the patient's treatment plan with findings summarized in the medical record was completed at least once every 30 days as required by the Department of Human Services.  A telephone interview conducted on January 4, 2024, at approximately 11:45 AM with EMP8 confirmed the findings above for MR1, MR2, MR8 and MR9. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 03/30/2024The Executive Director of the Episcopal Campus, Temple University Hospital Inc. (TUH) is the Executive Owner of this Plan of Correction.During the annual 5100 licensure survey of the Episcopal Campus Behavioral Health Inpatient program, it was found that a summary of the plan of care was missing from the medical record. A request was made to the electronic medical record build team on January 9, 2024, to create a 30-day EPISCOPAL CAMPUS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH INPATIENT PSYCHIATRY SUMMARY PROGRESS NOTE to serve as the patient progress summary note in the electronic medical record.  On January 15, 2024 clinical leadership met to discuss operationalizing the EPISCOPAL CAMPUS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH INPATIENT PSYCHIATRY SUMMARY PROGRESS NOTE to ensure completion every 30 days. Policy TUHE 109.000 Treatment Plan was reviewed and section 3 was updated accordingly.  Education about this requirement, the policy change and the new note template will be communicated to all treatment team disciplines (nursing social work, behavioral health therapists and psychiatrists) by February 28, 2024.   Sustainability is identified through the results of monitoring or auditing for the below data elements. When the results do not meet the benchmark, additional actions are implemented using the plan-do-study-act (PDSA) performance improvement process. Results are re-monitored or re-audited. Remediation with individuals is conducted when an issue is identified. Once the template is created and available in the electronic medical record, the Executive Director of Episcopal Campus and/or his designee will audit weekly 100% of patients with lengths of stay longer than 30 days to ensure completion and timeliness of the EPISCOPAL CAMPUS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH INPATIENT PSYCHIATRY SUMMARY PROGRESS NOTE in the medical record.  Anticipated audit compliance is 100%. Auditing will continue for the length of the action plan ending April 30, 2024.The Executive Director of Episcopal Campus and/or his designee will submit the results of this weekly audit to the senior leadership team representing social work, nursing, behavioral health therapy and psychiatry, weekly via email. Audit results will also be shared with the Episcopal Campus Performance Improvement Committee and the Episcopal Campus Regulatory and Accreditation Committee prior to the completion of the plan of correction. Information about this citation and related plan of correction was presented to the Behavioral Health Oversight Committee of the TUH Inc. Board of Governors on February 2, 2024., Audit results and a monitoring and sustainability recommendation will be reported to the Behavioral Health Oversight Committee of the TUH Inc. Board of Governors on April 26, 2024. 5100.16 (a) REQUIREMENT Review and Periodic Re-examination: 5100.16  REVIEW AND PERIODIC REEXAMINATION	(a) At least once every 30 days, every person in treatment under the Act shall have his treatment plan reviewed. Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted on May 25, 2023, for Temple University Hospital, Inc., for the installation of a nurse call system, located at 3401 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA., 19140. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was not in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted on May 25, 2023, for Temple University Hospital, Inc., for the installation of a nurse call system, located at 3401 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA., 19140. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was not in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction: 153.1 (a) LICENSURE MINIMUM STANDARDS:153.1  Minimum standards (a) Hospital construction shall be  
in accordance with the standards set  
forth in the latest edition of the  
Department of Health and Human

14500 Regulations, published under

except as modified in this chapter. (b) Hospitals previously in

Facilities, DHHS Publication No. (HRA)  
14500 Regulations, will be deemed in

shall meet the current edition. (c) A hospital shall meet the  
edition of the National Fire  
Protection Association 101, Life  
Safety Code, and all applicable  
appendices which are currently  
enforced by the Federal government.  
Hospitals previously in compliance  
with prior editions of the Life Safety  
Code will be deemed in compliance with  
any subsequent codes with the  
exception of any new renovations or  
construction, which shall meet the  
current edition.Observations:Based on observation, a review of the Facility Guidelines Institute Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospitals ("FGI Guidelines"), and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to install a nurse call system in accordance with the FGI Guidelines to ensure the provision of safe patient care in the emergency department.Findings include:A review on May 25, 2023, of the 2018 Facility Guidelines Institute Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospitals ("FGI Guidelines"), section 2.1-8.5.1.2 "Patient call stations" revealed "(3) The patient call station shall activate signals as follows: (a) A visible signal in the corridor at the patient's door. In multi-corridor patient care units or patient care areas, additional visible signals shall be installed at corridor intersections. (b) A visible and audible signal at nurse call duty stations in the locations listed below: ...(iii) Medication preparation room."An observation on May 25, 2023, at 2:45 PM with EMP1, EMP2 and EMP3 in the Emergency Department (ED) "Overflow/Minor Care" area revealed ED rooms 1 through 8 was on one side of the corridor.  Further observation revealed the area's medication preparation room was located around the corner from the patient rooms.  Further observation revealed there was no nurse call duty station in the medication preparation room.An observation on May 25, 2023, at 2:50PM with EMP1, EMP2 and EMP3 in the ED "Green Zone" revealed ED rooms 37, 38, 39 and 40 was on one side of the corridor.  Further observation revealed rooms 41 and 42 was located around the corner from the corridor such that the visible signals outside rooms 41 and 42 was not visible from the main corridor.  Further observation revealed there was no additional visible signal installed at the corridor intersection.  An interview conducted on May 25, 2023, at 2:55 PM with EMP1 and EMP2 confirmed the nurse call system was not installed in accordance with the 2018 FGI Guidelines to ensure the provision of safe patient care in the emergency department. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 07/31/2023The Vice President of Facilities is the Executive Owner of this Plan of Correction.On June 12, 2023, a nurse call duty station was installed within the TUH Inc. Main Campus Emergency Department (ED) medication preparation room and a visible signal was installed at the ED "Green Zone" corridor intersection to rectify the 2018 FGI Guidelines non-compliance. A review of nurse call compliance including staff drills will occur in all three Emergency Departments on the TUH Inc. license: Main Campus, Jeanes Campus, Episcopal Campus by July 15, 2023.To prevent future non-compliance with nurse call bells, all construction projects will be surveyed for nurse call by the Facilities and Regulatory teams prior to any request for a Pennsylvania Department of Health Division of Acute and Ambulatory Care occupancy survey. The nurse call review will be documented and filed and available to a surveyor upon request.Sustainability is identified through the results of monitoring or auditing for the below data elements. When the results do not meet the benchmark, additional actions are implemented using the plan-do-study-act (PDSA) performance improvement process. Results are re-monitored or re-audited. Remediation with individuals is conducted when an issue is identified.The Vice President of Facilities and/or his designee will audit 100% of construction projects for proof of a compliant nurse call survey within 90 days of written receipt of approval by the Pennsylvania Department of Health Division of Safety Inspection and prior to any requests for a Pennsylvania Department of Health Division of Acute and Ambulatory Care occupancy survey. Anticipated audit compliance is 100%.The Vice President of Facilities and/or his designee will submit to the Environment of Care Committee the results of the nurse call surveys, which will be shared with the Performance Improvement (PI) Committee, Medical Staff Executive Committee and Professional Affairs Committee of the Board of Governors through the governance process beginning in July 2023.Ongoing reporting to governance committees will continue through the life of the action plan ending July 31, 2023. To ensure ongoing compliance after the conclusion of the formal action plan, in August 2023 the Executive Owner will make a recommendation to the Performance Improvement Committee as to a Monitoring and Sustainability Plan. 153.1 (a) LICENSURE MINIMUM STANDARDS: 153.1  Minimum standards (a) Hospital construction shall be

It was determined the facility was in compliance with requirements of the Chapter 5100 Mental Health regulations. Plan of Correction: § 51.3 (a) LICENSURE NOTIFICATION:51.3 Notification (a) A health care facility shall  
notify the Department in writing at  
least 60 days prior to the intended  
commencement of a health care service  
which has not been previously provided  
at that facility.Observations:Based on a review of facility documents, observation, and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to notify the Department of Health (the "Department") in writing at least 60 days prior to modifying space on the hospital grounds to create a new consultation room for discharged patients.Findings include:A review on January 12, 2023, of facility presentation "Temple University Hospital Episcopal Campus" revealed "Patient Experience Enhancements. ...Community Provider Meeting Room + Linkage to Intensive Case Manager." An observation conducted on January 12, 2023, at 2:30 PM with EMP4 and EMP8 revealed Room MAB L01B (Community Provider Meeting Room) was located on the terrace level of the Medical Arts Building of Temple University Hospital Episcopal Campus.  Further observation revealed Room MAB L01B contained a couch, a desk, office supplies, and miscellaneous furniture toward the rear of the room.  An interview conducted on January 12, 2023, at 10:30 AM with EMP7 and EMP8 confirmed the facility had recently converted Room MAB L01B, previously a storage room, in the Medical Arts Building to create space for a Community Provider Meeting Room.  EMP7 and EMP8 further confirmed the "Department" had not been notified 60 days in advance as required.  An email communication received January 12, 2023, at 5:14 PM, authored by EMP9, confirmed the facility created space for community providers to meet with discharged behavioral health patients prior to the patient exiting the Episcopal Campus. EMP9 wrote "...regarding the new Community Provider Meeting Room on the Episcopal Campus: ...In order to increase access to community services, we created space for community providers to meet with recently discharged behavioral health patients. In May 2022, we created this space on the terrace level of the Medical Arts Building....The meeting room had previously been used to store administrative supplies. If the recently discharged patient is agreeable to the meeting, staff escorts the discharge patient to the room for a visit with an Intensive Case Manager..." Plan of Correction - To be completed: 06/30/2023The Executive Director of the Temple University Hospital Inc. (TUH, Inc.), Episcopal Campus has ultimate responsibility for the implementation and monitoring of the action plan.  Use of the Episcopal Campus community meeting room for discharged patients will be modified effective February 13, 2023.  Effective February 13, 2023, the meeting space will be available for individuals (former patients) and community case managers following at least one day (post) discharge.  Leadership on all TUH Inc. campuses will be provided education specific to the 60-day written notification requirements to the Department of Health, Division of Acute and Ambulatory Care (DAAC) prior to starting new patient services no later than March 30, 2023.  Education will be provided by the Chief Regulatory Affairs Officer and will include information specific to notification for change of use of space and also responsibilities for recently discharged patients. Information regarding 51.3 notification requirements will also be included in new employee orientation onboarding information in the Regulatory module.Sustainability is identified through the results of monitoring or auditing for the below data elements. When the results do not meet the benchmark, additional actions are implemented using the plan-do-study-act (PDSA) performance improvement process. Results are re-monitored or re-audited. Remediation with individuals is conducted when an issue is identified.To ensure compliance with notification of any proposed space changes the Chief Regulatory Affairs Officer will meet monthly with campus leadership and the Vice President of Facilities to review any proposed changes in use of space and ensure a corresponding notification has been sent to DAAC. All changes will be reviewed (Sample size is 100% of total volume) and an audit of corresponding notification letters confirmed at 100% compliance.The Chief Regulatory Affairs Officer will submit to the Environment of Care Committee 51.3 notifications to DAAC on a monthly basis, which will be shared with the Performance Improvement (PI) Committee, Medical Staff Executive Committee and Professional Affairs Committee of the Board of Governors through the governance process beginning in March 2023.  Ongoing reporting to governance committees will continue through the life of the action plan ending June 30, 2023. To ensure ongoing compliance after the conclusion of the formal action plan, in July 2023 the Executive Owner will make a recommendation to the Performance Improvement Committee as to a Monitoring and Sustainability Plan. All education, sign-off sheets, audit results, Committee and Board minutes, and other pertinent documents are maintained and available upon request for review by the surveyors. § 51.3 (a) LICENSURE NOTIFICATION: 51.3 Notification (a) A health care facility shall

periodic work performance 
evaluations.Observations:Based on a review of facility policy, personnel files (PF) and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure annual work performance evaluations were completed in accordance with facility policy for five of five personnel files reviewed (PF7, PF10, PF12, PF13 and PF14).Findings include:A review of the facility policy "Performance Management ("We Perform"), TUHS.HR 950.530" dated September 28, 2021, revealed "SCOPE This policy shall apply to Temple University Health System, Inc ("TUBS") and all TUHS (Temple University Health System) subsidiary corporations. ...Unless superseded by provisions of a collective bargaining agreement (which will prevail except in the case of Leaves regulated and protected by government mandate), this policy applies to all TUHS employees with the exception of the following: a) physicians employed by all TUHS entities... b) advance practice providers employed by Temple Physicians, Inc.; c) student workers/student assistants; d) interns and e) consultants on payroll within all entities. ...POLICY On an annual basis, TUHS will evaluate each employee on the following: (1) established goals that are specific, measurable, attainable, relevant and timely (SMART), (2) the "Everyone Leads" leadership competency model, and (3) TUHSs Core Values. Evaluations must be completed for every employee subject to this policy by June 30 of the current fiscal year with the exception of those employees hired on or after April 1 of the current fiscal year."A review on January 13, 2023, of PF7, a security officer, revealed PF7 completed new employee orientation to the facility on March 19, 2019.  Further review revealed no documentation that PF7 had annual performance evaluations completed in the years 2020, 2021, and 2022.A review on January 13, 2023, of PF10, a security officer, revealed PF10 completed new employee orientation to the facility on November 1, 2021.  Further review revealed no documentation that PF10 had an annual performance evaluation completed in the year 2022.A review on January 13, 2023, of PF12, a security officer, revealed PF12 completed new employee orientation to the facility on November 17, 2021.  Further review revealed no documentation that PF12 had an annual performance evaluation completed in the year 2022.A review on January 13, 2023, of PF13, a security officer, revealed PF13 completed new employee orientation to the facility on July 20, 2021.  Further review revealed no documentation that PF13 had an annual performance evaluation completed in the year 2022.A review on January 13, 2023, of PF 14, a security officer, revealed PF14 completed new employee orientation to the facility on March 19, 2019.  Further review revealed no documentation that PF14 had annual performance evaluations completed in 2020, 2021, and 2022.A request was made on January 13, 2023, at 1:10 PM of EMP5 and EMP30 for the annual performance evaluations for PF7, PF10, PF12, PF13 and PF14.  The facility was unable to provide the requested documents.An interview conducted on January 13, 2023, at 1:15 PM with EMP5 and EMP30 confirmed the facility did not conduct annual performance evaluations for security staff. Further interview confirmed annual performance evaluations were not conducted for PF7, PF10, PF12,  PF13, PF14 for the years 2020 through 2022.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 06/30/2023The Chief Human Resources Officer of the Temple University Health System (TUHS) has ultimate responsibility for the implementation and monitoring of the action plan.   Effective February 17, 2023 the security services contracted company is required to conduct a performance evaluation ("PE") of each staff member who is assigned to a Temple University Hospital, Inc. (TUH, Inc.) entity. A PE will be completed for all current staff assigned to TUH, Inc. by March 15, 2023. Moving forward, the PE must take place no less frequently than annually.The TUHS Chief Human Resources Officer ("CHRO") or designee will send an email to the security services contracted company informing them of the above defined system change. An email response from the security services contracted company attesting to compliance with these requirements will serve as proof of education. This will be completed by February 28, 2023.Sustainability is identified through the results of monitoring or auditing for the below data elements. When the results do not meet the benchmark, additional actions are implemented using the plan-do-study-act (PDSA) performance improvement process. Results are re-monitored or re-audited. Remediation with individuals is conducted when an issue is identified.To ensure compliance with the PE requirement the CHRO or designee will conduct a monthly audit of 10% of the security services contracted company staff who are assigned to TUH, Inc. to ensure that a PE has been completed. This audit will continue until such time that a 100% compliance rate is achieved in four consecutive months.The CHRO or designee will report the monitoring results at the April 4, 2023 Performance Improvement (PI) Committee, April 20, 2023 Medical Staff Executive Committee Meeting and at the March 29, 2023 Professional Affairs Committee of the Board of Governors. Ongoing reporting to governance committees will continue through the life of the action plan ending June 30, 2023. To ensure ongoing compliance after the conclusion of the formal action plan, in July 2023 the TUHS Chief Human Resources Officer or their designee will make a recommendation to the Performance Improvement Committee as to a Monitoring and Sustainability Plan. health examinations and of subsequent 
health services rendered to the 
employes as are necessary to ensure 
that all hospital employees are 
physically able to perform their 
duties.Observations:Based on a review of facility policy, personnel files (PF), and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure the required health evaluation and screening process was completed for new employees prior to beginning work in accordance with facility policy for  four of eight personnel files reviewed (PF7, PF8, PF11 and PF13). Findings include:A review of facility policy "Employment Procedure for Filling Positions" dated November 17, 2022, revealed "III. Policy. A candidate's offer of employment is contingent upon the completion of employment history verification, pre-employment background checks and pre-employment health evaluations and screens... D. Pre-employment Evaluation and Screening 1. Satisfactory completion of the pre-employment health evaluation and screening process is a requirement of employment for all external applicants.  Therefore, new employees must complete the required pre-employment health evaluation and screening process before beginning work."A review on January 13, 2023, of PF7, revealed PF7 completed orientation to the facility March 26, 2019. Further review revealed the document "Episcopal-Occupational/Employee Health" dated April 1, 2019.  Further review revealed a PPD skin test (for tuberculosis screening) was administered April 1, 2019, and "Not Read" was entered in the column for Date Read.  Further review revealed a PPD skin test was not completed until December 1, 2021. A review on January 13, 2023, of PF8, revealed PF8 completed orientation to the facility January 10, 2023.  Further review of PF8 revealed there was no documentation of pre-employment health evaluation and screening.  A review on January 13, 2023, of PF11, revealed PF11 completed orientation to the facility on July 8, 2022. Further review of PF11 "Security Clearance" form revealed a PPD skin test was administered December 13, 2022, and read on December 13, 2022.  A review on January 13, 2023, of PF13, revealed PF13 completed orientation to the facility on July 20, 2021. Further review of PF13 "Security Clearance" form revealed the "Date of Physical" was February 23, 2022, a PPD skin test was administered February 23, 2022, and read on February 25, 2022.An interview conducted January 13, 2023 at 1:10 PM with EMP5 and EMP30 confirmed the required pre-employment health evaluation and screening process for PF7, PF8, PF11 and PF13 had not been completed prior to beginning work at the facility in accordance with facility policy. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 06/30/2023The Chief Human Resources Officer of the Temple University Health System (TUHS) has ultimate responsibility for the implementation and monitoring of the action plan.  The personnel files of the non-compliant employees identified upon survey were updated to a compliant status within one week of survey.Effective February 17, 2023 the security services contracted company is required to ensure that each staff member who is assigned to a Temple University Hospital, Inc. (TUH, Inc.) entity undergoes a pre-employment health evaluation before they begin on-site work.All security services contracted company staff assigned to a TUH, Inc. facility will be notified by the security services contracted company account manager prior to the assignment start date that all required health screenings must be completed prior to reporting for first day of work. The security services contracted company will prevent a staff member from reporting to their TUH, Inc. assignment if that staff member had not completed all required health screenings prior to the start date. The TUHS Chief Human Resources Officer ("CHRO") or their designee will send an email to the security services contracted company informing them of the necessity to complete a pre-employment health evaluation before initiating work at a TUH, Inc. site. Observations:Based on a review of facility policy, personnel files (PF), and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure the required health evaluation and screening process was completed for new employees prior to beginning work in accordance with facility policy for  four of eight personnel files reviewed (PF7, PF8, PF11 and PF13). Findings include:A review of facility policy "Employment Procedure for Filling Positions" dated November 17, 2022, revealed "III. Policy. A candidate's offer of employment is contingent upon the completion of employment history verification, pre-employment background checks and pre-employment health evaluations and screens... D. Pre-employment Evaluation and Screening 1. Satisfactory completion of the pre-employment health evaluation and screening process is a requirement of employment for all external applicants.  Therefore, new employees must complete the required pre-employment health evaluation and screening process before beginning work."A review on January 13, 2023, of PF7, revealed PF7 completed orientation to the facility March 26, 2019. Further review revealed the document "Episcopal-Occupational/Employee Health" dated April 1, 2019.  Further review revealed a PPD skin test (for tuberculosis screening) was administered April 1, 2019, and "Not Read" was entered in the column for Date Read.  Further review revealed a PPD skin test was not completed until December 1, 2021. A review on January 13, 2023, of PF8, revealed PF8 completed orientation to the facility January 10, 2023.  Further review of PF8 revealed there was no documentation of pre-employment health evaluation and screening.  A review on January 13, 2023, of PF11, revealed PF11 completed orientation to the facility on July 8, 2022. Further review of PF11 "Security Clearance" form revealed a PPD skin test was administered December 13, 2022, and read on December 13, 2022.  A review on January 13, 2023, of PF13, revealed PF13 completed orientation to the facility on July 20, 2021.
